etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Jeffry Watts (d. 1663). From scribe + -ism

definitions: The doctrines and practices of the ancient Jewish scribes; the fact of conforming to these doctrines or practices. Also (rarely) in plural: attitudes or beliefs similar to those of the scribes.

notes.text: Sometimes depreciative, with reference to the legalistic or hypocritical character commonly attributed to the scribes in the New Testament.
